title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds a lack of reliable statistical information on franchise businesses, leading to misleading data in promotional materials. The United States Department of Commerce's reports on franchise business prior to 1987 are often misused. Franchisees can face significant losses due to inaccurate information. The purpose of this Act is to provide comprehensive statistical information on franchising, enhance the reliability of information available to the public, and ensure prospective investors have the necessary information to make informed decisions. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. Filing of Franchise Disclosure Documents-- All individuals or entities selling franchises must submit a copy of the disclosure document to the Commerce Department. The document should be the most recent version with current information and the most restrictive version provided to prospective franchisees. The franchise agreement outlines limitations on franchisee rights and remedies. The disclosure document must be filed annually with the Commerce Department, which will provide copies to Congress and other federal agencies upon request. It is illegal for franchisors to falsely claim that a disclosure document has been filed with the Commerce Department. The Commerce Department will establish procedures for compiling statistical information on franchise ownership and practices using disclosure documents filed annually. This data will include total numbers of franchisors and other relevant information. The Commerce Department will compile statistical information on franchise ownership, including total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover in ownership, and franchise failures. They will consult with various organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data compilation and analysis. The Commerce Department will compile statistical information on franchise ownership, including total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover in ownership, and franchise failures. They will also initiate periodic questionnaires of franchisors or franchisees to supplement information in disclosure documents, with a report to be published annually on franchise ownership and national franchising practices. The Commerce Department will compile statistical information on franchise ownership, including total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover in ownership, and franchise failures. A report on national franchising practices will be published annually and transmitted to Congress and the public through the Superintendent of Documents. The Commerce Department will compile statistical information on franchise ownership, including total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover in ownership, and franchise failures. A report on national franchising practices will be published annually and transmitted to Congress and the public through the Superintendent of Documents. Additionally, there will be a focus on census data specifically related to franchise businesses. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consulting with the Federal Trade Commission and Congress to establish criteria and data categories. A report on cost-effective data collection methods will be submitted to Congress within 280 days. The Bureau of the Census will include categories of data related to franchise businesses in the Business Census, consulting with the Federal Trade Commission and Congress to establish criteria. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to create rules and regulations to implement the Act, including fees for filing requirements. Definitions are also provided in the Act. The Act defines key terms related to franchising, such as "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise," outlining the nature of commercial relationships between franchisors and franchisees. The Act defines key terms related to franchising, such as "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise," outlining the nature of commercial relationships between franchisors and franchisees. Franchising involves distributing goods or services where the franchisee must adhere to quality standards set by the franchisor and operate under the franchisor's trademark or commercial symbol. Franchising involves the franchisor providing knowledge, assistance, and control to the franchisee, who must make payments to the franchisor as a condition for operating the franchise. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, while a "franchisor" is the one granting the franchise. A "subfranchise" involves a person paying for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees.
